Description: Rim sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed (fired red) below; exterior: glazed line at top of lip, reserved below; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this cup, the type belongs to his Type 9B South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 9B cups closely follow the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape.
Bibliographic references: Bernand 1970 / Le Delta égyptien d'après les textes grecs, i: les confins libyques (p. 698, no. 553)
Edgar 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis. B: The Inscribed and Painted Pottery (p. 54, no. 31)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.579) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
